context: Exposure of human lung epithelial cells to the aromatic hydrocarbons styrene or chlorobenzene at indoor relevant concentrations could be correlated with increased amounts of secreted inflammatory mediators such as monocyte chemoattractant protein 1 (MCP-1) and IL-8 (Fischäder et al., 2008; Lehmann et al., 2008; Röder-Stolinski et al., 2008a,b). MCP-1 is an inevitable factor in recruitment of inflammatory cells, such as eosinophils and monocytes in lung allergic inflammation and other pulmonary disorders (Conti and DiGioacchino, 2001), whereas IL-8 acts as a potent chemoattractant for neutrophils (Baggiolini et al., 1995). As we have shown previously using the human lung epithelial cell line A549, oxidative stress and the redox-sensitive NFκB pathway are directly involved in the induction of MCP-1 by styrene or chlorobenzene (Röder-Stolinski et al., 2008a,b; Mörbt et al., 2009). Additionally, recent results implicated that expression of several markers for oxidative stress such as glutathione S-transferase π1 (GSTP-1), heme oxygenase-1 (HO-1) and superoxide dismutase-1 (SOD-1), and expression of cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2), the key enzyme of prostaglandin pathway, are upregulated in the presence of chlorobenzene (Feltens et al., 2010). COX-2 is known to play a critical role in respiratory inflammation, involved in the pathogenesis of lung diseases (Park and Christman, 2006). In contrast to the constitutively expressed COX-1 form, COX-2 expression is induced by inflammatory and mitogenic stimuli (Vane et al., 1998; Lasa et al., 2000) and is regulated by p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) in different cell types (Schieven, 2009). Several lines of evidence indicate that COX-2 derived prostaglandins are associated with chronic diseases, including inflammation and cancer (Vane et al., 1998; Wang and Dubois, 2008).
